bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J. F. Siler, December 29, 1945

div1.p: Hench tells Siler about dining with Lawrence and Landon Reed, and Lawrence Reed's thoughts about the disbursement of funds from the Walter Reed Memorial Association.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J. F. Siler, December 29, 1945
div1.opener:
December 29, 1945
Colonel J. F. Siler
Gorgas Memorial Institute
1835 Eye Street N. W.
Washington, 6, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
After a very busy time in the Surgeon General's Office, I
was inactivated December 18, and arrived home just before Christmas.
It was wonderful to be with my family again.

I thoroughly enjoyed our pleasant visit and I am very pleased
at the honor bestowed upon me at my election to the Board of Managers
of the Walter Reed Memorial Association.

General Reed invited me for dinner at his home the night before
I left. I had a delightful time. Indeed, it was too delightful and I
actually didn't leave until 12:30: We talked about many things, and
General and Mrs. Reed seemed genuinely pleased that I had been elected
to the Board. This led General Reed to discuss the possible future use
of the funds and I was glad to get his own ideas representing those of
the family. He personally hoped that the funds could be given to Blossom
after his mother's death. Thereafter, he favored their use for a living
memorial, particularly if the funds could be amplified sufficiently.

I have no doubt that you have discussed this with him from
time to time or at least know his thoughts in greater detail than I do.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
